subSubSection.paragraph:
Abdominal gills very broad with ventral recurved flaps ( Fig. 21c ); foreclaw with double row of long denticles ( Fig. 21a )............................
Callibaetis floridanus Banks
Abdominal gills oval or elongate-oval without ventral portion or flap ( Fig. 20d–e , 22c–e , 27 ); denticles on foreclaw absent ( Fig. 22a ) or present and short ( Fig. 25 , 33a )............. 6

Abdominal segment 1 without gills, gills present on 2–7 only ( Fig. 20d ); caudal filaments with two distinct color bands ( Fig. 20e–f )...............
Americabaetis naranjoi (Kluge)
Abdominal segments 1–7 with gills; caudal filaments without distinct bands............. 7
— Claws apparently without denticles ( Fig. 22a ), although minute denticles may be present basally

Body length of mature nymphs < 3 mm ; abdominal tergum 9 with lateral white marking and with darker dorsal coloration ( Fig. 33b–c ); claws with row of minute denticles basally ( Fig. 33a ); outer basal margins of tibiae and tarsi without rows of setae...................................................................
Paracloeodes lilliputian Kluge

Body length of mature nymphs> 3 mm ; abdominal tergum 9 variable but without white lateral marking; claws without denticles ( Fig. 22a ); basal margins of tibae and tarsi with rows of setae ( Fig. 22b )...................................................
Cloeodes
(9)

Color pattern somewhat variable, but middle abdominal terga (5–6) without contrasting dark marks in anteromedian margin ( Fig. 22c–f ).................
Cloeodes superior Kluge
Color
pattern variable ( Fig. 23a–b,d ), but middle abdominal terga (5–6) usually with anteromedian,

contrasting dark marks ( Fig. 23a–b ).......................
Cloeodes inferior Kluge

Frontal margin (frons) of head flat, without keel between antennal bases ( Fig. 24c ); foreclaw with one long subapical seta ( Fig. 25b ).............................
Caribaetis
(
11) Frontal margin (frons) of head with keel between antennal bases ( Fig. 24a–b ); foreclaw without apical seta ( Fig. 25a )..............................................
Fallceon
(13)

paragraph.keyLead:
11(10). Abdominal terga 2, 6–7 uniformly dark brown; terga 4 and 9 pale, other terga variable but usually with some submedian markings ( Fig. 32a–b )...
Caribaetis alcarrazae (Kluge)
— Abdominal terga 2, 6–7 with weakly indicated markings on beige or brown background, terga 4 and 8–10 with similar markings on beige background ( Fig. 30–31 )................. 12

12(11). Mature nymphs relatively large (7.5 to 8 mm body length); dorsal margin of femora with many setae; rare...............................
C. grandis (González-Lazo and Salles)

— Mature nymphs small ( 3 to 5 mm body length); dorsal margin of femora with few setae.............................................................
C. planifrons (Kluge)

13(10). Abdominal gills 2–6 relatively long and narrow, at least as long as two abdominal segments ( Fig. 27f–g, 28 ).....................................
Fallceon longifolius (Kluge)
— Abdominal gills 3–6 more oval ( Fig. 27a–e ), not more than 1.5 times length of an abdominal segments.................................................................... 14

14(13). Distal segment of labial palp apically broad ( Fig. 26a ); paraglossae narrow and pointed apically ( Fig. 26a ); rare...........................................
F. testudineus (Kluge)

15(14). Abdominal gills widest medially ( Fig. 27a–d ); common.................
F. poeyi (Eaton)

— Abdominal gills widest distally ( Fig. 27e ); rare.......................
F. sextus (Kluge)
